guide.title: Quick Guide
guide.whatIsThisDesc: AI Canada Pulse automatically scans 6 data sources every few minutes to find AI-related signals: news articles, policy documents, research papers, code repositories, and funding announcements. Think of it as a news radar for Canadian AI.
guide.readingDashboardDesc: The numbers at the top show how many new signals arrived in the last 15 minutes, 1 hour, and 7 days. The feed below shows individual items. Colors indicate categories: blue for policy, teal for research, purple for industry, amber for funding.
guide.usingFiltersDesc: Use the command bar below the header to narrow results by time period, category, province, or keyword. Try the Scenario buttons for pre-built views like Policy Pulse or Risk Watch. Click any signal card to see its full details.
guide.modesAndViewsDesc: Policy Mode shows a streamlined briefing. Research Mode reveals extra analytics panels, charts, and data export tools. Use the Canada and World links to switch geographic scope.
guide.learnMore: Full details on the Methods page

methods.title: How It Works
methods.body: AI Canada Pulse collects, scores, and displays AI-related signals from across Canada and the world. Here is how the process works, from raw data to the charts you see on the dashboard.

dataSources.title: Where We Get Data
dataSources.intro: We pull from six different data sources to provide a well-rounded picture of AI activity:
dataSources.openalex: OpenAlex indexes millions of academic papers worldwide. We search for AI-related research, especially from Canadian institutions like Mila, Vector Institute, and Amii.
dataSources.govCanada: Government of Canada official news releases from Innovation, Science and Economic Development (ISED). Covers policy announcements, consultations, and regulatory updates.
dataSources.betakit: BetaKit is Canada's leading tech media outlet. We track their AI-tagged articles for startup funding rounds, product launches, and industry moves.
dataSources.googleNews: Google News aggregates AI-related coverage from thousands of Canadian and international outlets, giving us the broadest media perspective.
dataSources.github: GitHub repository search finds open-source AI projects with Canadian connections, including work from major research labs and universities.
dataSources.arxiv: ArXiv hosts preprint research papers before formal publication. We search for AI papers with Canadian author affiliations.

pipeline.title: How We Process It
pipeline.intro: Every signal goes through a four-step pipeline before appearing on your dashboard:
pipeline.collectDesc: Automated workers check each source every few minutes. They pull metadata: title, URL, publisher, date, and any author or entity information.
pipeline.scoreDesc: Each signal receives a confidence score (0 to 1) based on how relevant it is to Canadian AI. Factors include mention of Canadian entities, provinces, and known organizations.
pipeline.categorizeDesc: Signals are sorted into categories (Policy, Research, Industry, Funding, News, Incidents) and tagged with relevant jurisdictions (provinces, countries).
pipeline.displayDesc: The dashboard renders signals in real time via server-sent events. Charts, KPIs, and feed items update live as new data arrives.

numbers.title: What the Numbers Mean
numbers.intro: Here are the key metrics you will see on the dashboard and what they represent:
numbers.signal: A signal is a single piece of AI-related information that our system has detected and classified. It could be a research paper, a news article, a policy document, or a code repository.
numbers.confidence: Confidence Score measures how sure our system is that a signal is genuinely relevant to Canadian AI (0 to 1). Signals below a minimum threshold are filtered out.
numbers.hhi: The Herfindahl-Hirschman Index (HHI) measures how concentrated signals are across a dimension (sources, jurisdictions, categories). Low means diverse; high means concentrated.
numbers.riskIndex: The Composite Risk Index combines incident ratio, low-confidence share, and alert severity to give an overall risk snapshot. It helps flag emerging concerns.
numbers.momentum: Entity Momentum tracks how frequently specific organizations or people appear in signals over time. Rising momentum means increasing activity or attention.

limitations.title: Limitations
limitations.intro: This dashboard is a helpful overview, but it has some important constraints to keep in mind:
limitations.a: We only store metadata (titles, URLs, dates). We do not store or display full article text.
limitations.b: Source coverage depends on API availability. If a source API is down, signals from that source will temporarily pause.
limitations.c: Confidence scoring is rule-based, not AI-powered. It may occasionally misclassify signals.
limitations.d: The dashboard tracks what is publicly available. Private research, classified government documents, and paywalled content are not included.

faq.title: Frequently Asked Questions
faq.a1: Every few minutes. The live feed updates in real time via server-sent events, and charts refresh automatically.
faq.a2: Yes. In Research Mode, you can export signals as CSV or JSON using the export buttons in the feed header.
faq.q3: Why are some signals marked as low confidence?
faq.a3: Signals with weak connections to Canadian AI (e.g., a paper that mentions AI but has no Canadian authors or topics) receive lower confidence scores.
faq.a4: The dashboard interface is available in English and French. Signal content may appear in any language, with a language tag for each.
